headline: Heavily redacted documents share new details of Flynn's 2017 FBI interviews
subHeadline: Former White House National Security adviser in court after release of a heavily redacted FBI 302; reaction and analysis on 'The Five.'

The sentencing for Mike Flynn being pushed back until March, after a dramatic day in court. The federal judge saying he was disgusted with President Trump's former national security advisor for lying to the FBI and warned that he could be sent to prison. The judge also sparking a media firestorm after questioning whether Flynn committed treason before walking back his comments. utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, I think to myself, well, there's military justice. Let it proceed. Why is the president getting involved in this except that, as Jesse points out, he's watching Fox and he sees a mention of it and thinks he's going to do it. The reality is that -- not that this guy was even sort of a Hollywood hero, is that he took a prisoner off of the grounds and executed him. Now, I don't think that's a hero to anybody because once you're a prisoner you're not a combatant. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb17', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb17', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.sentences: They're debating whether --

But I don't think that you can't -- if you believe in law and order, have the U.S. military acting, especially U.S. members of the U.S. military acting out of line in terms of order in terms of the law and expect that people will respect us. If you're in Afghanistan you want people say, you know what, the United States stands for what is right in this world, not that they're a bunch of murderers. Â PERINO: All right. utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yeah. And I think that's fine for him to say that he's reviewing it. He hasn't said what he's going to do about it. We've covered this over the weekend. I was on that show with Pete. We've drew a lot of attention to it. But I -- we got feedback from a lot of military members, and what they were saying was that there so much bureaucracy now and the rules of engagement have gotten so out of control.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Convoluted, right? Confusing?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yeah, they're confusing. The troops on the ground don't -- they often times are like, what do we do here? We have what we consider to be the enemy. This is a huge threat. These catch and release programs scares the heck out of them because they're afraid if you take somebody who you know is a threat and then you release them, not only does that person become a threat then to your men and women and to yourself, but also to say if you're in Afghanistan, to the Afghanis --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: -- who are then helping you out, that then they're going to go on target. So, I think something has to be done. I do think the death penalty being on the table for somebody like this is a little crazy. I mean, this is someone who remember is out there on the front lines fighting to protect himself, his men, to keep the bad guys away. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb18', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb18', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

That becomes a problem

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS

utterances.speaker: PERINO

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: President Trump introducing new recommendations to make schools safer, what he's saying about arming teachers and a controversial Obama-era rule, that's next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: President Trump's school safety commission formed in the wake of the Parkland shooting, releasing its final report today addressing school violence across America, among the dozens of recommendations, giving states or local school districts the options to arm teachers and other school personnel. The president explaining some of the recommendations here. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb20', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb20', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: PRESIDENT DONALD TRUMP
utterances.sentences: These include fixing mental health laws so that families and law enforcement can get treatment immediately to those who need it. Allowing highly trained school personnel to have access to firearms. According to the department of homeland security, the average duration of an active shooter incident at a school is under 5 minutes. That is why it's critical to have armed personnel available at a moment's notice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: So, Jedediah, the arms -- the guns thing, some people including some students at the school are saying, wait a second. We thought that the emphasis should be on keeping guns away from young people. The commission says, oh, oftentimes they get the guns from adults and the like, and they suggest giving guns to the teachers or the personnel. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Keeping guns away from the bad guys is what we want. You know, I like the idea. Remember, that these people that are going to be trained, they're going to get background checks. You're not just handing guns to any old people. Oftentimes it's military vets or people that used to work in law enforcement that are retired that I think would be a great option for people to come to the school and protect it. I think it's important because a lot of these schools that are in very rural communities, they get really nervous about if you call. You know, we're use -- I'm used to living in the city. You call the police, you know, you think, OK, they're going to be here really quickly. If you're in a more remote area, if you call for assistance, by the time those people can get to you, a lot of damage can be done. So, you need to have people that are on those sites that are able to -- you know, that are trained and are able to do that. A lot of people say, oh, well, you know, the classroom is too chaotic an environment. It's not safe. I can say as having worked in a classroom it would make me feel really comfortable if I had people that were trained and were carrying so that I knew that if there was a bad guy with an agenda that had a plan to do damage that they would be able to protect me and the kids.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Jesse, another controversial element of the report was rescinding Obama-era guidelines that said, you know, we want to make sure that there isn't some kind of racial bias or bias against kids with disabilities in terms of school discipline. So, instead of suspending or throwing them out, which is what I think happened with this kid, Nikolas Cruz, that instead you would do things like counseling, therapy, support of the like. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm sensitive to -- if there's, you know, racial disparity in enforcing rules and they call it a school to prison pipeline, and I get that. But I think what happened is, is they took a bad situation and I think the mechanism they used to correct it overcorrected. So now you have -- you're selling drugs, you're punching people in the face, you're hurting girls, you're disruptive and disrespectful to the teacher, they don't do anything to you. What -- we have one teacher in South Carolina said, you have a kid who finds out that you can say F-you to the teacher, flip over the table, run out of the classroom, can't suspend them. So once the kid knows you can do that, they'll do anything. So all they're saying is instead of putting them into these diversion programs like they did with this guy in Broward County, maybe if he does something terribly wrong, you have to hit him with a criminal charge. And I think that's a good idea. if (window && window.foxstrike && Array.isArray(window.foxstrike.cmd)) { window.foxstrike.cmd.push(function(Strike) { Strike.insertAd('desktop', 'lb21', 'desktop-desk-ad-lb21', ''); }); } else { console.error('Error: window.foxstrike not found'); }

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: OK. And, Dana, what do you make of the idea that you would have such a recommendation about guns and discipline coming out of the Parkland shooting. It wasn't as if the shooter was some, you know, hard minority kid, thuggish kid or something. That's not what happened here. But it seemed like the president and Betsy DeVos have used this as a ground now to institute the policy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I don't think they used it. I think that it happens -- that they needed to do this report anyway. There was pressure on the administration to look at some of the things that Obama had done, and they decided to do something different. And what I like about all of the report is that it's saying let local school districts decide. And I think that is where we need to be -- what we need to be doing, that those decisions are best made by the communities. And they know, as Jedediah was saying, some are rural communities. Some are urban communities. Let them decide. Including on discipline. I picked this up. I printed it, and I will share with you, Juan, if you want. But USA Today had 15 teams, and -- reporters, and they went out, and they followed teachers for an entire day, one day in September all across the country. It is shocking what these teachers have to go through. They deserve a lot more of our support, financial support. Some of that's the case. But also safety, from outside the classroom and also from inside the classroom. There's problems, too. So I'm all for this report. I think it's good that they put it out.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And the -- but the teachers and the parents, Greg, according to the polls, don't support arming people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I -- I've seen different statistics including in Parkland, that are welcoming a lot of these changes. What I find interesting is that if you look on social media or if you just look at the media in general, how sanctimonious they were when they're saying, like, "no more thoughts and prayers." People would say, "It's time for action." This is action. I mean, look -- it's multifaceted. Banning of bump stocks. We don't know if that's going to change anything. It wasn't in Parkland, but it was used in other crimes. Then you've got psychiatric -- changes in psychiatric and counseling, things like that. You have the armed protection piece. And you're allowing the administration to act. See, the whole point of this other stuff. They're fearful of enforcing any laws, because they're afraid of being punished themselves for being racist or whatever. That doesn't have anything to do with this guy, except that it allowed him, the program allowed him to get away with it. So what you're doing is, a lot of this stuff is based on research and not on emotion. No. 1, we know that deterrence works. Killers will choose a gun-free zone over the opposite. Any deviation from that is generally an accident. But they will -- if they see even an empty, parked cop car, they will drive by that. That's all you have to do. And the length of a gun attack is mitigated by the appearance of a second gun. So when somebody shows up and knows how to use the gun, the incident shrinks. So those are the facts that are based on this. And I think this is well- rounded. I think everybody gets something out of it. A lot a lot of gun- control people, they didn't like the bump stock stuff. We'll see if that helps. We -- then if you goe armed personnel that are trained, that will help. So I think everybody gets something out of it. And it's -- people keep saying we have to act.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: We have to act. And I think that was the last thing? A judge ruled that police have no duty to shield students in the Parkland massacre. That was ruled. It's -- it's incumbent for you to be individually protected if that's the case.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But by the way, there was was a guy on site with a gun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, but he didn't act.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, I'm just saying. He was there.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: And one is not going to be enough.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: And poorly trained.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Poorly trained, all right. But -- well, you heard it here.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He didn't go in.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Well, but you know what? The thing is what you hear is that you're going to have more incidents of people using guns improperly if there are more guns in a school --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There's no science --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- where kids act up. Kids are kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There's no science behind that. No science.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Not if they're trained.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. Up next, my professor, Greg Gutfeld --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes!

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- offers his sage advice for how you can avoid embarrassing yourself at an office Christmas party. Very relevant to this group tonight.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Straight ahead.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: So our Christmas party is tonight. We were going to call it holiday celebration, but we're not wimps. It's Christmas. Now, since I'm old, I've been asked how does one survive such events? My advice: Be the least memorable person in the room. Don't try to be witty. Don't dance. Don't decide it's time to give Mabel -- Mabel -- some helpful advice about her breath. Now about the drinking. The older you are, the less you should drink. With one caveat: if you're in your 20s, right, you can have six drinks.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Six drinks!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Absolutely. Because I'll tell you later. In your 30s, you can have four. In your 40s, it's three. In your 50s, two. If you're in your 60s, you pay for the party, and you stay home.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Is that right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But if you're in your 70s and 80s, you can drink all you want. Here's why. Young people can drink more, because it's their nightly routine. It's all they do. They're the pros. However, middle-aged drunks think booze makes them young again. So they always wake up next to Human Resources. As for the old folks, you've earned the right to cut loose. Steal an ashtray. No one's watching, sadly. Now, you'll be among people you'll see next year and they'll remember everything you do. So don't remove your pants and dive into a snow bank. It took me years to live that down. Plus, everything is recorded now. The Uber driver sees all and will post it. Remember that. Stupid stuff lives forever, and the Christmas party's where stupid can really shine. My advice: drink water, become best friends with a house plant, and maintain a ruthless stoicism in the face of all flirtation. Boil down to two words. Be Pence. Be Pence, and you'll be safe. True, you will be the most boring person on earth. Or maybe people will think you're stoned. But when you sober up, you'll still have a job. You know, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Juan is paying for the party.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Yes, because I'm 60 -- I will be 65 next year. I can't even have a drink.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, it's for -- these things are for people in their 20s and maybe 30s. Right? Isn't it really? Because, like, they're -- it's for the single people to get drunk and have fun. We just have to sit there.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Now wait. Wait, wait, wait. I thought you gave me something to look forward to. That when I hit 70 and then 80 --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: But you know what? Because nobody cares about us then. We can just sit there -- unless you own the company. If you own the company and you're in your 70s, everybody is like this. But if you're just 70, they're like, "Ehhh."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I mean, we used to have legendary parties here back in the day around Christmas. We had an ice luge at one party. I called the police want time to report something missing. I wore a Santa suit one time. We had dance offs. We had awards shows. We had --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Where was this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: -- private videos.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Where was this?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Here!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Oh, at Fox?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes! Legendary parties back in the day. Now they're just tame. Now, I'm hosting this one at my place. And I'm thinking about canceling it. Because it's going to be boring, because you have all these rules, Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I don't have rules. I'm just trying to help.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I thought they were pretty lenient rules.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, they're pretty --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I would never, ever tell -- young women in your 20s, do not drink six drinks at parties. Do not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Have you seen -- women can drink.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, here's the headline. Gutfeld says, "Women in their 20s at Fox, drink six drinks at my Christmas party."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It was a generic. And I didn't say what kind of drinks. They could be nonalcoholic, Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That's fine.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I meant six nonalcoholic. Thanks, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Nice recovery.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: The problem with the drinks, too, is like I'm a talker. So then you reveal all the stuff you're not supposed to say, your life story. And then you forget that you told that person, and you show up to work; and they're like -- oh, what are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, that is so true.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Right?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know the worst person ever? This happened last year. I don't know if you remember this. The person who uses a Christmas party to network. Do you remember that?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Remember who I'm talking about?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: The kid with the cards.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The intern?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. Brought business cards.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: That wasn't last year, was it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Maybe it's two years.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It was a while ago. No, no, yes. He was a real -- he worked the system.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I think I pulled him aside and I said, "Stop giving your cards out to people."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, but now he's an executive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, he's actually my boss.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: So it worked.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, well, you know what? It's not for you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The thing about our party is that you cannot agree on a music selection.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Right? It's like you can't go to -- from death metal to country to whatever it is Jesse's week is to --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Tom Petty, baby.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, that's actually not bad.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Can I ask you guys this, though? Do you think it makes the party better or worse, safer or not, to have the significant others, the wives and husbands? See, I think that's how you make it safe.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Is that people behave better.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: You're like "No"? No?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, no, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Because you just don't want to pay extra if that's how we're going to have it.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's too expensive.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The whole time you have to be like, "Oh, and Peter, this is Jason. Jason wrote some" -- blah, blah, blah. And then basically, you're working, and you don't get a chance to actually just --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes. And my spouse hates everybody at Fox. Just hates --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Hey!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I'm joking. Maybe. I don't know.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think you're joking.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: It's -- it's a cost issue. I -- but I think the most important point here is about the Uber thing. Everybody talks about --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: What are you talking about? They take pictures of you?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I'm -- well, they have a camera on there. And all the people who get in trouble on Uber are drunk, right? They're always in the back, yelling at the poor driver. We think that at the party, it's the problem. It's when you leave.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Leave, yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: And you're like -- you're like, "Hey!" and you get in a -- you start berating a taxi: "How come" -- you know, that kind of thing.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: True.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: It's different now, though.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I think drinking and driving is a problem.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: In New York, it's -- but it's easier now to not drink and drive.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: But not if you're -- even in the suburbs in some cases. And I mean, in the restaurant industry, of course, is concerned about this, because they don't -- they have a high profit margin on selling alcohol. But I think, you know, it's damaging.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Uber is everywhere.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's true.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I don't know. I hope it's everywhere. By the way, my wife, because I had to go to a lot of parties in Washington for many years, just stopped going.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know why?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Good advice.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And you know why she stopped? Because she said she would go up and people would meet her, famous people and they'd say, "What do you do?" And she'd say, "I'm just -- you don't need to talk to me. I'm Juan's wife."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That's --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: And then they would be looking over her shoulder.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: You know what? That's the same thing -- that's Elena, has had that experience. And it's like "I design. I'm a fashion designer."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Screw yourself."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: "I don't need this."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: "So what if you're president?"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, exactly. Up next, why witches are fuming over Trump's favorite line of attack on the Mueller probe, ahead.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: The witch hunt as I call it. You know I call it a witch hunt, and it is a witch hunt. How long has this witch hunt gone on?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: President Trump's frequent nickname for the Mueller investigation is upsetting actual witches. The witch community now furious with the president and, dare we say, is flying off the broom handle. Many are now complaining Trump is demonizing and marginalizing the so-called minority group by bringing up its painful history. Now, Juan, the witches are saying, "Listen, there was a time in political history when we were hunted down. We were killed for being witches. This is bringing up a painful memory." Do they have a point?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: You know, I don't -- I don't -- I didn't -- I don't -- I was in Seattle the other day --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: He's speechless.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Are you a witch?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: I was in Seattle the other day, walking down the street, and there are people who were a coven, I guess, Jedediah. I was so lacking in sympathy. I was a little afraid of them, you know. But anyway, I guess that, you know, they have something to say; and I understand that they have now cast a spell --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: A few of them, yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- on President Trump. Because they said if it was an actual witch hunt, he would have been -- would be on a beam in some kind of farm house --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: -- that was cold and killed. And that's how they treated witches in the old days. But instead, he's going down to Mar-a-Lago for Christmas.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes. I mean, I wouldn't want to --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: For 16 days.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I wouldn't want to anger the witches, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: No.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's just not -- I wouldn't want them casting a spell on me. But they make the bigger argument, of course, that they're a minority group and, like other minority groups that Trump has been antagonistic towards, they're speaking for other people and broadening it out. What do you think?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, we'll have a witch on "Watters' World" this weekend this weekend to respond to some of these new claims.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Excellent.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You think I'm kidding. I'm not.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I know you're not.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Sadly, I'm not. You know, I'm very vexed by this whole situation. The president has conjured up a lot of wicked language to describe Mueller, the special counsel's cauldron. It's been brewing for almost two years. And I'm sure Trump just wishes he can wave his magic wand and make Mueller disappear. I mean, even the left's spellbound at how this has lasted so long. You have 13 angry Democrats exposing the dark underbelly of the Trump campaign, warts and all. I think clearly, Trump just believes he's cursed by Jeff Sessions recusing himself.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Was that Greg? I think -- I think Greg is having an impact on you.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I know. I'm hanging out at this table for too long.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You had a little extra time today.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: So well-prepared.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You haven't done that for a while. I like that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Only once in a while.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Especially because it makes Greg laugh.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's true. You know, I've anticipated a lot of things with this administration, but the witch community coming out like this, I didn't see this coming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Some of them are good people.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: There is a bit of cultural appropriation going here in the progressive modern witch community. The witches that were burned at the state, 50,000 were burned or drowned. They were not a protected class. They were not cool or hip. They were falsely accused of being witches. That's the history, and they died. It's a terrible -- it's a terrible part of our history. It happened in America. What was it, around the 1600s? I don't know. But I think overall, including Europe, it was like 50,000 people. So I think that witches should be actually fighting a real battle about -- over freedom to speak, freedom to practice religion, to exercise your beliefs rather than this silly stuff.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Wait a minute. Somebody doesn't let them practice? I thought - - I see them --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No, I'm just saying for everybody else, they should be standing up for everybody else's rights to speak.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: But you took this segment seriously.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: He did. He really did.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I did.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He put a brain room request in on witch deaths.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, I did. You know, Wikipedia just makes me slightly smarter.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Dana, any last thoughts on witches?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, I think that they could use it to their advantage. Right? The more he says witch hunt, the more possibility they have for branding. And I mean, a lot of people, they could turn this into a positive. If they were smart.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: That's true. Maybe they will.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Maybe they could wiggle their noses, and it would just go away.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I loved Elizabeth Montgomery.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: There are good witches, too. Everybody thinks --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Good witches.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Elizabeth Montgomery, had that crush when I was a kid.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes, a lot of people did. Glinda, the good witch in "The Wizard of Oz."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Not crazy about her.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I was a big fan. All right. "One More Thing" is coming up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Time now for "One More Thing." Do you guys remember that David Schwimmer lookalike that got caught stealing beer in Britain?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: The Jesse Watters lookalike?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes, kind of looked like me, everybody said? Well, here's the deal.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Jesse holding a case of lite beer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: No, no! Producers, very funny. It's not me. This guy, Abdulah Husseni, is in trouble with the police over there. He skipped out on his court appearance. There he is.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That does not look like me.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, it does.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That's definitely Schwimmer.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: It does look like Schwimmer.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: It's definitely Schwimmer. So he faces charges of theft and fraud. So he's on the loose. A Schwimmer/Watters lookalike is on the loose. Call your local authorities. Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: You should have him on the show this weekend.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I should.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes, with the witch.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: After the witch or before?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: I think after. A draw.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what? I'll tee up Schwimmer. I'll tee Schwimmer and have the witch hunt.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Exactly. All right. Over the weekend, surfer Kelly Slater pulled this off. Watch this. It's called the Houdini Tube Ride. After falling off his board but getting back on it mid-wave and finishing out.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: So he is apparently amazing, and this doesn't usually happen. This is at the Billabong Pipe Masters in Hawaii and, despite his miraculous move, however, Slater couldn't make it out of the semifinals this year. But this is what amazes me. He's 46.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Dana, he's like -- he's the greatest surfer that probably is living right now, Kelly Slater.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: He's like the Jesse Watters of surfing.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: He's been surfing since he was two.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Well, don't you think it's impressive he can still do that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I -- 46 is young for a surfer.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Is it?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Greg, can you swim?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: No. And I was a lifeguard. I don't even know what --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Wow, I feel sorry for that pool. All right, Greg, you're up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I was a pool monitor, so legally, I wasn't allowed to save people. Isn't that amazing? All right. It's time for --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: A whole nother story.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- yes.

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.sentences: Greg's The True Meaning of Christmas

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: "Greg's the True Meaning of Christmas." A lot of people think I'm a grinch, but I'm not. I do find special moments in the holiday season that make me smile. One of the things I love to do is to understand what it's like to be a Christmas tree, like this young man did. As you see him now run and dive through a --

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Awesome!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: That was a Christmas tree packaging machine, and he actually got wrapped up with the tree --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: -- which in some states is considered deviant. We -- we don't condone this. Do not replicate this in your Christmas tree lot that many people have.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: We should try this. Let's try this at our Christmas party tonight. I'm going to run you through.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Exactly, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That was a good "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Thank you very much. I've got the "Animals are Great."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Don't ruin it with that. Juan Williams.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: All right. At Fox news, we report, you decide. So take a look at the story of a secret Santa gift exchange. Here are the basics of the story. A woman receives a blanket and chocolate as a secret Santa gift from a coworker. Now, take a look at how she responds in this text message. That's right. She Googled the price of the chocolate and the blanket.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: It added up to 30 bucks. Then she gets upset, because the spending limit was $50. She then asks the gift giver, her co-worker, to give her something else, give her more, even give her the added 20 bucks. She even said, "Why not buy me a $120 computer tablet?" Well, the coworker refused on both fronts.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.sentences: Who's right? Who's wrong? In this modern tale of Christmas conflict, I say this woman ends up on Santa's naughty list. But we report, you decide. What do you say, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: I say top that, Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Well, I've got some baby humans. One of my -- two things I love most, everybody knows, baby animals and baby humans. Today we have some baby humans. The Oak Ridge Fire Department, cutest picture ever, in Tennessee, welcomes six new babies within a nine-month period. Two boys, four girls. Mason, Evelyn, Ezekiel, Wayland, Henry and Blaine. Fire department posted the photos to Facebook, and they wrote, "From the month of March until the month of November, the Oak Ridge Fire Department has welcomed six new members to our family. We're beyond excited. Congratulations."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Looks like they were starting some fires.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: Yes, they were.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Know what I'm saying?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. Nine months ago.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: But look how cute they are. There's something about babies and small animals that --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Really, do you find that? I've never heard that before. You think babies and puppies are adorable? That's never crossed anybody's mind.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I know. Listen, I break news every day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: I've never seen calendars with puppies.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: You know what? Can we show Greg's guy running through the Christmas tree netting thing again, producers? I think the audience deserves another -- there we go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Whoa!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.sentences: Now that's cute. Don't do that, people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: That is good.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.sentences: I'll give you five bucks if you do that tonight.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Now we're all going to go to the Christmas party at my apartment complex.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.sentences: Some of us will be here tomorrow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.sentences: Yes. You'll know who. All right. Set your DVRs, never miss an episode of âThe Five.â "Special Report" is up next with Bret.

utterances.speaker: BRET BAIER, HOST
